{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3219037,"name":"","username":"pocnic","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/ed655f/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-07-15T18:33:51.020Z","cooked":"

Recently, with more and more powerful swerve pods designed, I thought that I would throw my hat into the ring with a differential swerve that I feel is somewhat simpler to manufacture than other previous designs.

cad.onshape.com

Onshape

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 3 million users.

image864×761 93.3 KB

image750×590 60.1 KB

For starters, this design requires only 1 unmodified ttb bevel gear set, and minimal modification to COTS components. I will be iterating further to allow for all modifications to COTS components to be done on a manual mill or lathe.

image703×383 10.4 KB

(yes I realize that these calculations are done with falcons and the cad shows neos)

The drivetrain gear calculations are shown above. These gear ratios are not the easiest to change, but only require 4 different gears, and only 1 of those gears to be modified.

Furthermore from a controls perspective, I would imagine that both motors in the differential would be run at ~90% of their top speed allowing the last 10% to be used for rotating the modules. Essentially, there is always room to rotate the module while driving at full speed by reducing the speed of 1 motor to 80% and increasing the other to 100%.

As far as nice features that this module has here is a small list:
1:1 encoder for measuring rotation
4in OD x 2in WD 3d printed wheel tread
MK4i footprint
Minimal use of high strength 3d printed parts (more on this later on when I have time to write an explanation)

I have no intention of ever having this module manufactured, though I would really like for this module to be tested.

screws","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":16}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":16,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3219144,"name":"","username":"pocnic","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/ed655f/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-07-16T15:18:39.336Z","cooked":"

Since I posted this yesterday, I have assigned weight to all materials. Currently it sits at around 7.81 lbs. I already have identified several changes that will bring down the weight, and for the printed parts, I just assigned them as if they were completely solid parts (100% infill). If there is a way to assign accurate weight based on infill of printed parts I’d like to do that instead.

As such, I believe it is reasonable that this module will weigh under 7.5 pounds when (if) produced.

This is still heavier than a mk4i module plus an extra motor, so there is improvement that still could be made.

I also will be updating a few of the parts with minor improvements that should make manufacturing the module a little bit easier.

This looks really cool but after staring at the cad model for a while I still cant seem to understand how this differential swerve works. Any chance you could draw a simple diagram on how this works to turn/drive? Thanks for posting this model!

Team 5818 Differential Swerve Drive Technical Discussion
“Classic” Swerve: Motor goes roundy roundy, wheel goes roundy roundy. Another motor goes roundy roundy, wheel goes to specified angle. Differential Swerve: Motors go roundy roundy, wheel goes roundy roundy. Difference between motors going roundy roundy used to make wheel go to specified angle. Someone is going to think I’m being condescending and I’m not - it’s a riff of the famous “hot rock make boat go”.

Not a diagram but it might help if you’re struggling with what the difference between swerve and differential swerve is
